segments.Text:
This text was transcribed using whisper model: large-v2

 He did a terrific job closing Black Hat for those of you who were over at the Caesars.
Assistant Secretary of Defense and CIO of the Department of Defense with responsibility for command, control, communications and intelligence.
Just about takes care of everything.
He has an extensive background in industry as an engineer and he's also been president of a major defense contractor.
Next, Dick Schaefer.
Dick works for Mr. Money. He's the Director of Infrastructure and Information Assurance, DOD.
He's been in the information security business for over 25 years and he is a former U.S. Marine.
Next, Jim Christie.
Jim is a Special Agent in the Computer Crime Investigation Wing in the Air Force Office of Special Investigation.
He is detailed to Dick Schaefer in the Defense Right Information Assurance Program.
He is the Department of Defense representative to the President's Infrastructure Protection Task Force.
He was detailed to Senator Sam Nunn in the past and the Permanent Subcommittee on Investigations.
And he's Director of Computer Crime for the United States Air Force.
Last but not least, Dave Jarrell.
Dave is the Director of FEDCIRC or the Federal Computer Incident Response Capability of the General Services Administration or GSA.
This is the way we're going to do it.
Each person is going to take a couple of minutes to make a statement and then we will calmly, respectfully and with great dignity question the panelists.
Mr. Mulligan.
Thank you.
It's, I think, indeed a pleasure to be here.
Ah, come on, lighten up out here.
I've been asked so far today at least a dozen times why did I want to come here.
To me this is a unique opportunity to talk to you all as was it last night with the Black Hat Affair.
My job in the Department of Defense is in fact to keep what we call information superiority working.
Make information superiority work or happen.
What does that mean?
The premise, the vision, the Joint Vision 2010 that General Charlie Cachevilli laid down, who was the Chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff about three years ago,
has how America will fight and win future wars.
And what that talks about is dominant maneuver and precision engagement and things like that.
But wrapped around all that is information superiority.
And what does that mean is to ensure an uninterrupted flow of information to the warfighter and deny an enemy or an adversary that same.
It also means an uninterrupted flow in a business sense.
So I have two hats.
The C3I hat is the warfighter hat.
The CIO hat is more the business affairs or the revolution in business affairs hat.
And the two need to work in a seamless manner.
The DoD has roughly a $300 billion a year budget, which means about $35 million an hour, 24 hours a day, 7 days a week, 365 days a year is flowing somewhere.
Electronic commerce is very much important to us.
So at one end, getting information that a warfighter needs in a cockpit or in a foxhole or on a Humvee or on a ship.
At the same time, paying people, having the contractors paid and so forth.
All that needs to work in a seamless flow.
That may seem a little bit strange to you, but ordering a spare part from a battle should not need or does not need, cannot be interrupted any longer,
so that part gets to the right spot and so forth.
The same thing with blood supplies.
And we've had hackers hack into hospitals and change the polarity of the blood supplies.
That might sound like it's fun, giggles, shits and giggles, that kind of thing, but it's serious stuff.
People now die because they get the wrong blood.
Some of those people may be your brothers or sisters, your parents or whatever.
So that's one of the reasons I wanted to come here, to say,
it might be viewed as a challenge, it might be viewed as fun to hack in and screw around with some data,
but we're affecting the lives of people.
Maybe those are your brothers or sisters.
So that's one of the things that I wanted to get across.
The other thing is, to some degree, is to thank you.
Last year, Jim Christie and I think Jeff Hunker asked that you lighten up during the Y2K, during the millennia turnover.
And we had essentially very minimal hacker problems into the DoD last year over the turnover of the millennia.
That was good news because we were very heavily concentrating on terrorists infiltrating the United States.
Well-known ones coming across Port Angeles from Canada, coming into the northeastern part of the United States.
So our focus was clearly on what could lead up to not a cyber attack, but a physical attack.
So in that degree, I appreciate your cooperation.
My final message in the world of the Q&A is, in fact, there's a couple of messages I wanted to send.
If you're new, and obviously some of you are extremely talented, extremely talented and skilled, gifted even, at what you do.
If you're thinking about what you want to do the rest of your life, then maybe we ought to think of this in a slightly different manner.
And that manner is, come to work for us. Come to work with us. I'm serious.
There's a couple of great examples.
In a brochure I posted yesterday, John Merton, who used to attend this conference, is now a security consultant.
There's a great birth, there's a great need for security folks, for security consultants, for system administrators, for people who understand the new windows that we all practice.
In fact, to protect the country, to protect the military, to protect the country from the standpoint of what's going on.
We're no longer under attack in a hacker sense.
We had 22,144 attacks last year on DoD.
We know that because we have intrusion devices extensively placed now.
These were attacks, blatant attacks, not an occasional pain.
So we're getting, whatever that works out, seven or eight a day.
Some of these are now state-sponsored by other countries, or transnational problems, transnational groups coming in and attacking.
Maybe not just for shits and gibbles in that context, but actually to do much more serious damage.
So the whole game has changed.
A hole in the Solaris operating system that caused havoc two years ago isn't going to be as serious today.
But having much more subtle attacks, much more sophisticated attacks, and frankly what keeps me up at night are the ones that are out there that we haven't even detected.
The utility of the United States, which is the greatest nation in the world, this is a great witness of that.
Where else could this kind of a convention be held?
Where else could this happen?
So at the same time to preserve your rights, I support the Constitution of the United States, it's been confirmed twice.
Support the laws of the United States.
But at the same time to think about what are we doing in the future?
What are we doing now that will affect our lives in the future?
When I invite you to join the government, or the private industry for that matter, they get on the defense side.
Yes, the government has some offensive capability.
We don't talk a lot about that here.
But yet it's another weapon system in the quiver that we need to protect ourselves.
It doesn't, it isn't used.
It is only used with presidential authority as if it was nuclear release.
That's the severity of cyber attacks and how we work those in the United States government.
So I invite you to think about what you're doing today that may affect you in the future.
If you really enjoy what you're doing, and as I said a lot of you have talent in that way,
then join us. Join us in preventing, educating our people, preventing more serious damage to be done to the country in the future.
Thank you very much.
Thank you, Dick. Next up.
I just want to add a couple of words to what Art said.
And sort of put in perspective the operational environment in which we conduct our everyday operations.
I don't need to tell this group that it's a globally connected, interdependent environment.
It's commercially based. It's infrastructure, commercially infrastructure based.
And so when you're out there sort of running around the neighborhood, we're your neighbors.
And the sophisticated or the serious adversary that Art spoke to, and there are a lot of very, very malevolent characters out there.
Could be nation state, could be transnationals.
Our friend Osama bin Laden doesn't necessarily always have to use physical means to get his way.
But we're all out there on the same highway.
And the more that we interact, the more that we bump into each other,
the more we have to understand sort of the rules of the road and how we play.
Because in that environment, we don't know whether it's you or whether it's Osama bin Laden
or one of his compatriots that are trying to do something malicious against the U.S.
And there are many, many serious operations in which the U.S. engages
that we absolutely seriously depend upon that infrastructure in order to conduct that business.
And unless it's there, unless it's there when we need it,
unless it's there providing the capability that's essential to conducting the operation,
whatever it is, we're in trouble. We're all in trouble.
And the U.S. close partners and allies could be in trouble.
So I'd like to sort of foot-stomp what Art said.
Those of you out there who consider yourselves to be really good,
anybody can download scripts off the Internet and put them into the system and fly away,
and that's pretty easy.
But for those of you that are above that, are sort of the best of the best,
we've got some of the most sophisticated toys in the world,
much more sophisticated than what you've got in your basement, I guarantee you.
And if you'd like to get access to those toys and become part of a very, very elite team,
then we invite you to have a discussion.
And that doesn't necessarily mean U.S. government.
As Art said, there's a lot of contractors that we rely on to support us,
but I can guarantee you there's nobody here with the level of sophistication
that can be matched within the U.S. government,
and there's nobody here that has a set of toys that's anywhere near as neat as the stuff that we've got.
So with that, we had hoped that we'd have some military recruiters here,
just to sort of handle the onslaught.
So we do. Back in the corner there.
Just in case you're motivated.
So anybody at the conclusion of the conference that wants to sign on,
I guarantee you we're very interested in talking to you, but I'll just qualify that.
We're interested in talking to the best of the best.
If you're average, we don't really need you.
If you're the best of the best, then we're very interested.
Thank you.
Thank you.
Who's up?
Tim?
I'm going to make my statement right here real quick.
First off, I want to piggyback off what Mr. Money and Dick said,
but before we recruit you, you know, in God we trust, in others we polygraph.
So I just wanted to make that clear.
And I'm just here to trade T-shirts, so anybody who wants to trade T-shirts with me,
you know.
Okay, Dick.
I have a question. How many hackers in the room?
No hands?
Oh, come on.
Aren't you proud of what you do?
Aren't you proud of what you do?
I just wanted to emphasize something, building on what Art Money said a while ago.
There are those things that are done for education, for curiosity, and that's good.
That's how we learn.
But those of you who would enter into an event for the purposes of anarchy
or causing disruption of services to critical services where life and death and our way of life depend on it,
there's no glory in being an asshole.
Think about what you're doing, and think about the methods that you use
for drawing attention to yourself whenever you discover a vulnerability or a weakness
in the security posture of the system.
There's a right and a wrong way to go about it.
What I would ask of you is if you discover a weakness in a system,
rather than posting it on some chat line or an IRC or sharing it with your buddies,
pick up the phone and call me.
I'll give you the number. It's toll free.
It's toll free. It is 888-282-0870.
Call the Federal Computer Insert Response Capability.
We will take what you have learned and make a difference.
We will put into place protection mechanisms, or we will put into place patches where they're needed.
We know, the government is way behind on this, and we know that.
And we need help.
You're in a position to either help people or to hurt people very seriously,
and we would ask that you take a common sense approach to that and do the right thing.
Call us when you find something wrong. We'll fix it.
I'll give you a number for Dial-A-Prayer. How's that?
If you're good enough, you can find it, right?
Okay, you've had the challenge.
If when he gets home, his answering machine is connected to clubhuff.com,
then he'll know he's got somebody elite out there in the audience worthy of their attention.
Okay, ready for questions?
Sure, do it.
Okay, yes?
I have two questions for them.
I couldn't think of two points to state that.
The first one is you seem to condense scriptedness,
and the second one is that I know you, excuse me, say that you don't approve of open disclosures.
For the first point, I hear you saying that scriptedness isn't how you do it.
The truth of the matter is, it's not effective against your site.
You're continually predicated by digital vulnerabilities, the same misconfiguration,
how are you ensuring that that doesn't continue to occur?
And to what is your question addressed? Anybody in particular?
Okay, who would like to take that one?
I think your, let me work on your second point, is well taken.
Up until two years ago, system administrators, and I'll speak specifically and totally of the DoD,
Dave Jarrell with the Administration, he's broader in the government context.
Within that DoD, system administrators were very likely to have two or three other jobs
and then be a system administrator.
I've jokingly said, with some precision, that you may, in a post somewhere,
post camp base or station somewhere, you may be the mess officer or the motor pool officer
and then be the system administrator.
So it was viewed as an add-on task and not as a full-time job.
Consequently, the DoD had not trained folks very well,
nor had put into a discipline since when a vulnerability was found
that it needed to be patch corrected within a period of time.
Since Solar Sunrise, that has started to change.
You're red teamists every day, you all out here, and wherever your other folks might be.
Our red team is every day, so every day we're getting more robust, but frankly it's a pain in the ass.
It's a constant haranguing when we have more important things to do.
I'd rather have my resources diverted on what another state's trying to do to us,
another solving state that has attacked the United States,
has taken gigabytes of material, unclassified open material,
but nevertheless has taken it out in a data mining war.
I'd rather go after that kind of thing than being seven times a day in a number of places
trying to say, what the hell is this one doing to us?
So we're getting better, we've got a long way to go,
but we've upped the game tremendously on training and on full-time jobs for system administrators
and the discipline to fix those things when they become obvious they need to be fixed.
The Solar Sunrise problem that took us three weeks and so forth,
and those of you who heard me yesterday, the three weeks was mostly because of the arcane wiretap instructions
to go back and figure out who the attackers were, just took time.
So you have an antiquated law that takes physical appearance before a judge
with a pile of paper in a dynamic switching sense that could be milliseconds.
There's a great mismatch there that's starting to be changed.
Until that time, 70 or 80 percent of that attack could have been blunted
if the system administrators had put in the patch that was well known in the Solaris operating system,
they hadn't done it.
So we're getting better, yes, you can still find holes,
but I'll submit it's getting tougher every day for you to get in and screw around like you used to.
Frankly, because we've gotten more robust, we have a hell of a lot more search centers,
we have a lot more training and more discipline in the system.
Frankly, we'd rather devote our attention to a nation-state
that has probably a hell of a lot more of a different motive than a malicious attack.
Okay, another question? Yes.
I didn't say shoot them.
In a physical sense.
Let me repeat the question.
The questioner said that yesterday at Black Hat, Mr. Muddy spoke of influencing legislation
toward the direction of greater punitive measures directed against hackers,
up to and including assassination. Is that correct?
And you asked for clarification and amplification, especially the assassination part.
I think they might be paraphrased a little bit here.
Maybe that is being shot in an electron sense, not a physical sense.
So let me get squared out a little bit.
I don't want some sound bite going on over here.
The Assistant Secretary of Defense talked about assassination.
Back to them.
We may have a little electron attack going back the other way.
Electrons go both ways, you know.
Okay, come on, lighten up out there.
Let's see, the loss.
I'll say that one of the problems we have today, from my perspective,
is every attack is first viewed as a law enforcement issue.
Every attack is first viewed as a law enforcement issue.
A whole other set of prerogatives come into being.
Jim Christie can chime in here.
What that means is the protection of the privacy of the citizen.
I support that.
I support that.
I want to be protected as a private citizen as well.
But at the same time, that is also bringing us down, creating havoc.
I'll tell you, it was very painful to me when we saw the blood supply in a hospital get corrupted.
The polarity of the blood supply, of the blood was changed.
That's where all the men play in and out.
So we want to change some of this.
We have legislation proposed, not yet passed, not against the privacy of an American citizen,
but if an ISP or a certain phone number is used and it's in a protected entity,
meaning it belongs to the United States government as in the Department of Defense or something,
it is immediately a national security issue, not a law enforcement issue.
Then the game changes.
It's now not a law enforcement issue, it is a national security issue,
and then immediately tracing back, hacking back, shooting back, in an electronic sense, is within our prerogative.
So that's what's likely to change.
There's a great dilemma out there.
And the dilemma goes this way.
If it's a law enforcement issue, the law enforcement folks will most likely want to continue whatever it is that's going on
so they can gather enough evidence to prosecute.
From a DOD national security standpoint, we don't want to scroll around and wait for more evidence to be given.
We want to terminate whatever that problem is immediately.
Do you know about the prosecution?
We want to terminate that hemorrhage immediately and get on to something else.
So there's a built-in tension between the Department of Justice and the Department of Defense,
between the FBI and some of the units within the DOD.
Some of this will clarify that.
Immediately, today, it's a law enforcement issue.
Not everything is a law enforcement issue any longer.
Jim, do you want to add anything?
Just that today's laws make us, you guys don't have to necessarily play by the rules, but I do.
Otherwise, I go to jail, and they'd much rather put me in jail than put you in jail.
Trust me.
So it's much more difficult for us, and hopefully, with what Mr. Money and others are doing,
legislation will change and make it a lot easier to go back and identify, get attribution for an attack,
and do whatever we need to do, whether it's kill them or whether it's arrest them.
Electronically, sir.
You ain't kill them, so to speak.
With respect to the law enforcement issues, I do ask that we come to you first.
We discover a security issue.
Are you prepared to bring a broad range of new and sectoral issues together?
What is your response to the Department of Justice's request for the Department of Justice and other agencies
to investigate the issue?
Okay, two questions.
The first is, if we do come to you with information, are we protected from prosecution in the act of so doing?
And second, what's your stance toward releasing source code for programs like Carnivore and all the other sniffers that you have developed?
With regard to the first question, if you're probing a network,
if you identify an operating system or version that you know has a known vulnerability in it,
and you report that, you haven't done anything wrong.
You have not penetrated that system.
But once you cross that gray line and you gain unauthorized access to the system, now you've committed a crime.
Let me jump on that, too.
Let's say you break into some place and you discover, because you discover the vulnerability.
Don't tell me how you discover the vulnerability.
And if you don't like that one, then call in, in an anonymous sense, the CMU, Carnegie Mellon.
Pardon?
Call in an anonymous sense, call in or send in your information, to a halfway house, if you will, like at Carnegie Mellon,
where then that information can get to us, but the source of that information doesn't get to us, in that context.
We're for sharing information to prevent vulnerabilities, so we can strip off that, in that context.
In other words, if you're really serious about getting information through, use cutouts,
and make sure they pass through several hands to get there, and the information will get to the right hands, you can count on it.
I appreciate anonymous emails, also, that will give me a clue that something is weak,
and I pass it on to the responsible network administrator, so they can make it not so weak.
Okay, and the second question is about Carnivore's open source code for programs like it. One second.
Well, in law enforcement, first off, it's nothing but a sniffer, okay?
You know, OSI has the same sniffer we had at first, we call our sniffing.
For obvious reasons. So, it's, you know, system administrators' sniffers are probably more sophisticated.
Ours have all kinds of filters built in, because of what we can look at, what we can't look at, when we get a wiretap authority.
So, you're gathering, as a system administrator, a whole lot more data with your sniffer than the FBI is with Carnivore.
It's really filtered down, and we don't share our techniques.
I'm not going to show you our electronic surveillance techniques.
We just don't do that, because the reason is you guys build countermeasures.
So, we're not going to do that. Have a nice day. Sit down.
So, whoever called it Carnivore really botched it. That was the problem, calling it Carnivore.
Now, question here.
That's one of the reasons we're here.
I want to repeat the question, but I want to make sure I understood it.
You're saying that we're desensitized to violence.
That the DOD has evolved an alternative to violence, a different paradigm, which is to use cyber war, in effect, rather than lead bullets.
And you're asking, what can we do to shift the entire paradigm, the way we think about warfare and antagonism and defense, into that mode of operating?
You said to treat CNA as a virtual station, but as a real operator.
More honorable, we will drop a bomb on bullets.
What are we doing to change that?
I personally would have never electron shotted.
In other words, to use non-lethal weapons wherever we can.
But we want to shift that paradigm.
Okay.
I think you approached this in the right way.
The President, the Sikhs, the commanders and chiefs of the various regions of the world.
As you all know, we have conflicts ongoing.
We're trying to maintain peace in Kosovo, in the Balkans, in Bosnia.
We're trying to maintain peace and keep Saddam from invading another country in Southwest Asia.
Yes, we will worry and watch North Korea and other countries.
The state of affairs today in the world is, we used to be focused on, in the Cold War, with a non-lethal threat called the Soviet Union.
Rightly so.
They can do nanowaves.
They still have a thousand ACBMs and some 19,000 nuclear weapons.
They can still launch.
But a bizarre concept called NAD, Mutually Assured Destruction, which is bizarre as hell in my mind.
It says if you attack and drop one on me, we're going to attack and drop several on you.
That served us well.
We had a stability that we don't have today.
Osama Bin Laden does not worry about being assassinated or having part of his village wiped out.
So there's no NAD.
There's no Mutually Assured Destruction there.
So we have what we call an asymmetric threat.
An asymmetric threat, a terrorism attack.
The goal here is not to take on the United States in a friendly context anymore.
So I'm trying that.
It was wiped out in a hundred hours.
So the idea is to come after the United States in a roundabout asymmetric area.
Take down two embassies.
Kill 400 people in two American embassies in Africa.
Or take out a Marine barracks in Lebanon.
Or whatever.
Maybe someday, hopefully not.
But maybe someday it could be on the continent of the United States that this problem is.
So one of the concepts is to look more.
Give the President, give the National Command Authority more of a broader spectrum of responses.
The response today used to be drop an iron bomb on somebody.
Then the iron bomb had a precision guidance package so it could go in the particular window,
as you've seen in CNN, a particular window of ability.
Well today we'd like to have an even more broader response.
And sometimes that is to take down something in an electronic sense.
So a computer network attack is in fact coming out of the closet.
Last year, on October 1st, we transferred computer network defense to a SINC.
To a war-fighting SINC that then has different authorities.
That was Space Command.
This October, computer network attack will be transferred to Space Command.
So at the same time we'll have defense and we'll have offense very close to each other.
And there's logic behind that because some of this may be fracture-side to yourself.
So yes, it's coming out of the closet.
It's been viewed and it won't be discussed very broadly because, as you probably know,
some of these techniques and so forth are extremely fragile.
And it doesn't take much to counter them.
So we don't talk openly with any detail or any precision or any specificity about what we have.
But yet we have another, what I'll call another arrow in the quiver,
of how to respond to the war we live in.
Thank you. Does that answer your question?
Okay. Other questions?
I'd like to ask with regard to the 1999 report,
the GPO website regarding Chinese U.S. security,
how well do you know the future security in any way?
Is there a resistance to computer technology right now?
I think the question is, if we're going to protect ourselves,
why do we not do it unilaterally and ubiquitously? Is that correct?
So the first question is, are we in fact giving proprietary weaponry or aid and comfort to the Chinese
at the same time we're saying to our own citizens, don't?
I think there's been a, anybody want to?
I think there's been an uneven approach to this.
Much to maybe your disbelief, there is not a monolithic government in the United States.
There are several different factions.
People are people. People are doing what they think is right, by and large.
I think people are well-intentioned, by and large.
And their responses are uneven.
I think your point here with, it doesn't have to be the Chinese.
It can be the Israelis, the French, anybody.
Our technology is very much wanted in the rest of the world.
What complicates that is a lot of the technology is dual use.
If it's dual use, meaning it has some civilian or commercial value or application,
as well as a military value or application, it's called dual use.
One of those uses may in fact be classified or highly sensitive and so forth.
The other issue, the other is application is wide open.
That makes it very difficult to control or regulate.
So that's part of the unevenness.
There's also been some lack of discipline and sloppiness and relaxation and so forth.
All of that frankly goes with kind of a time cycle.
A lot of that is being tightened up now.
You listen to some of the scientists at Los Alamos having been polygraphed recently.
They didn't like that, but it was deemed necessary.
And they had two hard disks with lots of nuclear design secrets on it were lost.
So it's your goal to try to stay ahead of the game,
but yet some of the things have dual use, dual points of view, and that kind of complicates life.
Anybody else want to add anything to that?
No? Okay.
Over there.
Okay.
I just wish you would expand a little bit on the paradigm that you have.
You come in here, you scare us half to death with the blood system
and all these other international attacks that have happened.
But if you look at the media of what has happened in the past,
an example of this at Los Alamos,
the transfer of information of ballistic missiles for China for satellite control,
how are we supposed to weigh your being here,
talking to us and explaining to us about the diarist,
when we actually see what's really a bigger issue of the government transferring information to other governments,
without you guys really knowing about it.
So we're scared as hell.
They're scared as hell.
Now you're here to help us.
We need you to help us.
We don't know if we can trust you.
Okay.
So we have a question that comes out here.
And for those in anxiety,
we want to work with you.
We love you.
We're patriots.
But you just scare the hell out of us.
And besides, we have a high priority on consistency and rationality.
We see, as you said, things going from all different sources in so many directions.
We're trying to get our minds around that and understand what the hell is going on.
But you see what he said?
He's helped us here.
We're here to work with you, but help us out here.
Right?
How can we trust you?
Let's see.
I have four grandkids.
Some of them were about the age of 12, 13, 14.
Two kids and so forth.
So I mean, hell, they could be out there in that audience.
I'm here to protect the United States,
protect our right,
protect your privacy.
Now, at times we may be on the opposite side of the fence.
That's one of the reasons I wanted to come here.
And if I scared the hell out of you,
then in some respect that's good.
I thought it was common knowledge
that somebody has hacked into hospitals and changed blood types
or the polarity of blood types and that kind of thing.
If that was news to you,
then we need to be more open about some of the dire consequences
of some of the quote-unquote fooling around acts and so forth.
Back to the other point of the question
about transferring information to the Chinese or whatever.
That was started off as a belief
that the launch systems of the Chinese,
principally a system called the Long March,
which is a rocket,
was needed to in fact launch some U.S. commercial payloads.
Consequently, those companies in the U.S. were given the authority
through an export control system to talk to the Chinese.
There's different points of view on what happened.
Maybe more information was transmitted than was desired.
But that was not your government being malicious.
Instead, it was your government trying to accommodate
the lack of launchers in the United States
by giving those commercial companies more capability.
But to me, it shows an example of how complicated things have become
in the context of dual use again.
Dual use for a rocket, meaning to launch a commercial satellite,
that same bloody rocket then, once it has the capability
to launch a satellite into a particular orbit,
i.e. guide it to a particular spot in space,
is then obviously a better rocket to launch a missile
to hit the United States with some precision.
So again, back to the dual use.
To me, the hardest problem we have today is to sort out
what we're doing on side A in a commercial sense
and then the effect of that on side B.
I'll give you another example. Aviation.
Our whole aviation industry,
